verses.text: Soon afterward, Jesus traveled through cities and villages, preaching and announcing the good news of the kingdom of God. The twelve were with Him,
verses.comment: Jesus is depicted as proclaiming the kingdom of God personally, underscoring His role as the central messenger and fulfillment of Old Testament hopes. Note the twelve disciples accompany Him, underscoring the importance of apostolic witness.

verses.text: and certain women who had been healed of evil spirits and illnesses: Mary, called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had gone out,
verses.comment: The involvement of women like Mary Magdalene demonstrates their integral role in Jesus' ministry. Healing of demonic affliction points to Christ's authority over evil powers.

verses.text: and Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod's steward, and Susanna, and many others, who provided for them out of their resources.
verses.comment: Women supporting Jesus out of their resources highlights both their faith and an early pattern of communal support for the ministry. This anticipates the concept of stewardship in the later church.

verses.text: When a great crowd gathered, and people from every town came to Him, He spoke in a parable:
verses.comment: Parables are a means for Jesus both to reveal and conceal truth, inviting faith and reflection. See also Old Testament use of parables in 2 Sam. 12:1-4.

verses.text: "A sower went out to sow his seed. As he sowed, some seed fell along the path and was trampled underfoot, and the birds of the sky devoured it.
verses.comment: The sower is an image widely used in Scripture for God's Word, cf. Isaiah 55:10-11.

verses.text: Other seed fell on rock, and as soon as it grew up, it withered away because it had no moisture.
verses.comment: This signifies hearts that respond quickly but cannot endure hardship, lacking deep roots in faith and tradition.

verses.text: Other seed fell among thorns, which grew up with it and choked it.
verses.comment: Thorns recall the curse of Genesis, linking back to humanity's tendency toward distraction and worldliness.

verses.text: Still other seed fell on good soil, and it grew and produced a hundredfold harvest." As He said this He called out, "Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear."
verses.comment: The abundant harvest points to the effectiveness of God's Word when received with faith and perseverance. Echoes the prophetic call to listen with obedience.

verses.text: Then His disciples asked Him what this parable meant.
verses.comment: Seeking the true meaning of Jesus' words is shown as proper discipleship, anticipating the future role of church teaching authority in interpreting Scripture.

verses.text: He said, "To you it has been given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God, but to the others I speak in parables, so that 'seeing they may not see, and hearing they may not understand.'"
verses.comment: Jesus affirms that knowledge of God's mysteries is a gift, echoing Isaiah 6:9. Divine truth is entrusted to the apostles, establishing a precedent for apostolic authority in handing on faith.

verses.text: "Now the parable is this: The seed is the word of God.
verses.comment: God's Word here is living and active, see also Hebrews 4:12.

verses.text: The ones along the path are those who hear. Then the devil comes and takes away the word from their hearts, so that they may not believe and be saved.
verses.comment: The power of spiritual opposition is real. The imagery suggests the necessity of grace to resist the devil's influence.

verses.text: Those on the rock are those who, when they hear, receive the word with joy, but these have no root; they believe for a while, but in time of testing fall away.
verses.comment: Perseverance is necessary to remain in faith — see also the warning in Hebrews.

verses.text: That which fell among thorns are those who hear, but as they go on their way, they are choked by the cares and riches and pleasures of life, and do not bring mature fruit.
verses.comment: Worldly distractions can suffocate faith. Bearing mature fruit requires discipline and detachment from riches (cf. 1 Tim 6:9).

verses.text: But as for that in the good soil, these are the ones who, hearing the word, hold it fast in honest and good heart, and bear fruit with perseverance.
verses.comment: Faithful perseverance leads to fruitfulness, echoing the epistle's exhortation to be doers of the word.

verses.text: "No one, after lighting a lamp, covers it with a vessel or puts it under a bed, but sets it on a stand, so that those who come in may see the light.
verses.comment: The metaphor of light refers to faith and witness—intended to shine forth, not be hidden.

verses.text: For nothing is hidden that will not be made manifest, nor anything secret that will not be known and come to light.
verses.comment: Truth ultimately prevails and will be revealed. This applies both to personal character and divine revelation.

verses.text: Therefore, take heed how you hear. For whoever has, to him more will be given; and whoever does not have, even what he seems to have will be taken away."
verses.comment: Responsibility in responding to God's Word; those who embrace it receive more light, others lose even what they had.

verses.text: Then Jesus' mother and His brothers came to Him, but they could not reach Him because of the crowd.
verses.comment: The presence of Jesus' mother is an important detail, showing her ongoing role in the gospel narrative; 'brothers' in Jewish context can refer to kin or extended family.

verses.text: He was told, "Your mother and your brothers are standing outside, wanting to see you."
verses.comment: The repeated mention of His mother underlines her significance in Jesus' earthly life and in salvation history.

verses.text: But He answered them, "My mother and my brothers are those who hear the word of God and do it."
verses.comment: Spiritual kinship is based on hearing and obeying God's Word. Note that Jesus does not deny, but redefines, His relationship, pointing to a new spiritual family—a concept vital for church life.

verses.text: One day Jesus got into a boat with His disciples and said to them, "Let us go across to the other side of the lake." So they set out.
verses.comment: Crossing the lake sets up a demonstration of Jesus' power over nature, foreshadowing His divine authority.

verses.text: As they sailed, He fell asleep. A windstorm came down on the lake, and they were being filled with water and were in danger.
verses.comment: Jesus' sleep displays true humanity; His action in the storm soon after reveals divine power, as God alone stills the raging seas (cf. Ps. 107).

verses.text: They went and woke Him, saying, "Master, Master, we are perishing!" He got up, rebuked the wind and the raging waves, and they ceased, and there was a calm.
verses.comment: Jesus' authority over creation is a divine prerogative (see Job 38:8-11). This underscores His identity as the Lord.

verses.text: He said to them, "Where is your faith?" In fear and amazement they said to one another, "Who then is this, that He commands even the winds and the water, and they obey Him?"
verses.comment: The disciples marvel because only God rules the sea. A clear statement of the divinity of Christ, able to exercise God's authority.

verses.text: Then they sailed to the region of the Gerasenes, which is opposite Galilee.
verses.comment: Jesus moves beyond Israel's traditional boundaries, prefiguring the inclusion of the Gentiles in salvation.

verses.text: When Jesus stepped out on the land, a man from the city who had demons met Him. For a long time he had worn no clothes, and he did not live in a house but among the tombs.
verses.comment: The imagery of uncleanness points to ritual exclusion. Jesus' approach signals restoration and spiritual healing.

verses.text: When he saw Jesus, he cried out, fell down before Him, and said in a loud voice, "What have I to do with you, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you, do not torment me."
verses.comment: Even demons recognize Jesus’ divine Sonship, proclaiming what humans sometimes fail to grasp.

verses.text: For He had commanded the unclean spirit to come out of the man. For many times it had seized him. He was kept under guard, bound with chains and shackles, but he would break the bonds and be driven by the demon into the wilderness.
verses.comment: The destructive power of demons contrasts with Jesus’ liberating authority.

verses.text: Then Jesus asked him, "What is your name?" He said, "Legion," because many demons had entered into him.
verses.comment: 'Legion' evokes a host of hostile forces; Christ’s victory here foreshadows ultimate triumph over evil.

verses.text: They begged Him not to command them to go into the abyss.
verses.comment: The abyss is the realm of ultimate imprisonment and defeat for demonic powers (cf. Rev. 20).

verses.text: Now a large herd of pigs was feeding there on the hillside, and they begged Him to let them enter these. So He gave them permission.
verses.comment: Jesus' authority over demons extends to their final destination; pigs are considered unclean, hinting at a spiritual dimension.

verses.text: The demons came out of the man and entered the pigs, and the herd rushed down the steep bank into the lake and drowned.
verses.comment: The self-destruction of the unclean spirits shows their ultimate impotence before Christ.

verses.text: When those who fed the pigs saw what had happened, they ran off and told it in the city and the countryside.
verses.comment: Witnesses spread news of the miracle, foreshadowing the spread of the gospel.

verses.text: People went out to see what had happened. They came to Jesus and found the man from whom the demons had gone out, sitting at Jesus' feet, clothed and in his right mind. They were afraid.
verses.comment: Being at the feet of Jesus demonstrates discipleship. The people’s fear is a response to God’s holiness and power.

verses.text: Those who had seen it told them how the demon-possessed man had been healed.
verses.comment: Testimony to God's power in Christ prepares for faith in the wider community.

verses.text: Then all the people of the region of the Gerasenes asked Him to depart from them, because they were seized with great fear. So He got into the boat and left.
verses.comment: Fear may lead some to push God away. Jesus only stays where He is welcomed, a theme repeated in the Acts of the Apostles.

verses.text: The man from whom the demons had gone out begged that he might be with Him, but Jesus sent him away, saying,
verses.comment: Sometimes discipleship means witnessing in one's home community.

verses.text: "Return to your home, and declare how much God has done for you." So he went away, proclaiming throughout the whole city how much Jesus had done for him.
verses.comment: Jesus equates proclaiming what He has done with proclaiming what God has done—another affirmation of His divinity.

verses.text: When Jesus returned, the crowd welcomed Him, for they were all waiting for Him.
verses.comment: Jesus is consistently sought after by the crowds, recognizing His authority and bringing their needs to Him.

verses.text: And behold, a man named Jairus came, who was a ruler of the synagogue. He fell at Jesus' feet, pleading with Him to come to his house,
verses.comment: Jairus is a significant religious leader; his act of faith shows that submission to Christ is above all human rank.

verses.text: because he had an only daughter, about twelve years old, who was dying. As Jesus went, the crowds pressed against Him.
verses.comment: The detail of the daughter’s age (twelve) hints at fullness and readiness, often symbolic in scripture.

verses.text: And a woman was there who had had a discharge of blood for twelve years, who had spent all her living on physicians, but could not be healed by any.
verses.comment: Her lengthy suffering echoes ritual uncleanness preventing worship, pointing to Christ as the one who restores both to health and worship.

verses.text: She came up behind Him and touched the fringe of His cloak, and immediately her bleeding stopped.
verses.comment: Touching the fringe connects to obedience to God's law (see Numbers 15:38-39). Healing through touch is both physical and spiritual.

verses.text: And Jesus said, "Who was it that touched Me?" When all denied it, Peter said, "Master, the crowds surround You and press in on You."
verses.comment: Peter’s practical approach contrasts with Jesus’ divine awareness. This highlights both the reality of faith and the need for faith beyond what is seen.

verses.text: But Jesus said, "Someone touched Me, for I perceived that power has gone out from Me."
verses.comment: Jesus’ personal physicality is joined to divine power; healing flows from Him knowingly, emphasizing a real and substantial grace.

verses.text: When the woman saw that she could not remain hidden, she came trembling, and falling down before Him, declared before all the people why she had touched Him, and how she had been healed immediately.
verses.comment: Confession of faith before others is necessary for salvation, not just private belief.

verses.text: He said to her, "Daughter, your faith has made you well; go in peace."
verses.comment: Faith receives the gift that Christ gives; 'go in peace' signals reconciliation and total restoration.

verses.text: While He was still speaking, someone came from the house of the synagogue ruler and said, "Your daughter is dead; do not trouble the Teacher any longer."
verses.comment: Jesus is called 'Teacher,' but soon displays power beyond teaching—over life and death.

verses.text: But Jesus on hearing this answered him, "Do not be afraid; only believe, and she will be made well."
verses.comment: Trust precedes the miracle. Faith is the precondition to receiving God's life-giving power.

verses.text: When He came to the house, He did not allow anyone to enter with Him except Peter and John and James, and the child's father and mother.
verses.comment: Jesus selects three chief disciples as witnesses, highlighting an inner circle, a pattern for future leaders in the church.

verses.text: All were weeping and mourning for her, but He said, "Do not weep, for she is not dead but sleeping."
verses.comment: Sleep here symbolizes death as temporary when touched by God's power, anticipating Christ's resurrection.

verses.text: And they laughed at Him, knowing that she was dead.
verses.comment: The crowd’s disbelief contrasts with the faith Jesus requires. Human limitation meets divine power.

verses.text: But He, taking her by the hand, called, saying, "Child, arise!"
verses.comment: Jesus brings life with a word and touch; His command carries creative, divine authority.

verses.text: Her spirit returned, and she immediately got up. And He directed that something should be given her to eat.
verses.comment: That she eats is proof she is truly alive; Jesus cares for both spiritual and bodily needs, hinting at the reality of resurrection.

verses.text: Her parents were astounded, but He commanded them to tell no one what had happened.
verses.comment: Jesus sometimes asks for secrecy, possibly to avoid misunderstanding about His mission before the appointed time. This example of restoring life anticipates His own resurrection and the greater resurrection of all the faithful.
